subsc: Primary education,Law and justice,Central government administration
trustfund:
TF035931-BOLIVIA - ENVIRONMENT TECHNICAL
            ASSISTANCE PROJECT,TF020595-ENVIRONMENTAL TA PROJECT,TF023715-BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION
            PROJECT (BCP)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Environmental Technical
            Assistance Project (ETAP) in Bolivia were as follows:
            overall outcome of the project satisfactory, project
            sustainability was uncertainty, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were also rated satisfactory. Lessons
            learned includes: 1) the project was designed by an outgoing
            Government, and began to be implemented by a new Government
            only two months later. The program design was not consistent
            with the structure and goals of the incoming Government. It
            is clear from this experience that projects suffer when they
            are designed under one Government and executed under a
            subsequent one whose structure and priorities are distinctly
            different;  2) the project design did not adequately address
            what was meant by a "consultant", and ended up
            supporting far too many Government line positions as
            consultants. When the funding ended these people left and
            the Government was weakened by their departure; and 3) the
            project design did not adequately address the issue of how
            taxes were to be paid for by the Government, and what steps
            would be taken if the Government was unable to meet their
            tax liabilities. Similar problems arose with counterpart
            funds. The lesson is that solutions to these possible issues
            should be more clearly thought through before a project begins.
